title: Sofus Heggemsnes
text:
Sofus Heggemsnes (born 13 July 1999) is a Norwegian <a href="Artistic%20gymnastics">artistic gymnast</a> who competed at the <a href="2017%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2017</a>, <a href="2018%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2018</a>, and <a href="2019%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2019 World Championships</a>. He represented <a href="Norway%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics">Norway</a> at the <a href="2020%20Summer%20Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. He is a four-time <a href="Northern%20European%20Gymnastics%20Championships">Northern European</a> champion, as well as a World Cup bronze medalist.
Early life.
Heggemsnes was born in <a href="Oslo">Oslo</a>, <a href="Norway">Norway</a> to a Swedish father of <a href="Jamaicans">Jamaican</a> and <a href="Trinidadians%20and%20Tobagonians">Trinidadian</a> descent, and a Norwegian mother who was born in <a href="California">California</a>. He has a twin brother, as well as two older brothers and two older sisters.
Heggemsnes first took up <a href="Association%20football">football</a> as a child, and used to celebrate goals by doing cartwheels. A parent of another player suggested to his mother that she should enroll him in gymnastics. He started training in gymnastics at age nine.
Gymnastics career.
Heggemsnes has been training with his current coach Valentyn Skrypin since age 11. He made his international debut at the <a href="2016%20European%20Men%27s%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2016 Junior European Championships</a> in <a href="Bern">Bern</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, placing 42nd in the all-around during qualifications. Later that year, he competed at the <a href="2016%20Northern%20European%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2016 Northern European Championships</a> in <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a>, where he was part of the gold medal-winning Norwegian team. Individually, he took the silver medal in the all-around and on the pommel horse, and the bronze on the parallel bars.
Heggemsnes became a senior in 2017, making his international senior debut at the <a href="2017%20FIG%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20World%20Cup%20series">Varna World Cup</a> in <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, placing seventh in the pommel horse final. He went on to compete at his first <a href="2017%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">World Championships</a> in <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, but did not make any finals. In 2018, he competed at the <a href="2018%20European%20Men%27s%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">European Championships</a> in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, and the <a href="2018%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">World Championships</a> in <a href="Doha">Doha</a>, where he placed 40th all-around in qualifications, and 22nd with the Norwegian team. He also finished seventh on pommel horse at the <a href="2018%20FIG%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20World%20Cup%20series">2018 Guimarães World Cup</a>.
In 2019, Heggemsnes became the senior Norwegian all-around national champion and won a bronze medal on vault at the <a href="2019%20FIG%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20World%20Cup%20series">Szombathely World Cup</a> in <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>. He also had success at the <a href="2019%20Northern%20European%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2019 Northern European Championships</a> in <a href="K%C3%B3pavogur">Kópavogur</a>, winning the all-around title with a score of 80.950, and helping Norway take the team gold ahead of <a href="Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. He also won gold on floor, silver on rings, parallel bars and horizontal bar, as well as a bronze on pommel horse. Heggemsnes went on to compete at the <a href="2019%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">2019 World Championships</a> in <a href="Stuttgart">Stuttgart</a> where he placed 51st all-around in qualifications, scoring 79.623. His performance at the World Championships earned him an individual spot at the <a href="2020%20Summer%20Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>.
At the Tokyo Olympics, Heggemsnes competed on pommel horse, rings, parallel bars and the horizontal bar but did not reach the finals.
